news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-features/5526015/-confessions-of-an-art-sleuth.html|title=Philip Mould: why I love being a sleuth on art's treasure trail|last=Mould|first=By Philip|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> He has made a number of major art discoveries, including some of [[Thomas Gainsborough]]'s earliest known works,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/5407381/Rare-Gainsborough-uncovered-by-Antiques-Roadshow-presenter.html|title=Rare Gainsborough uncovered by Antiques Roadshow presenter|last=Millward|first=By David|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> the only known portrait of [[Arthur, Prince of Wales]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/d/Books/Trail-Lot-163-Search-Lost-Art-Treasures/1857025237|title=The Trail of Lot 163: In Search of Lost Art Treasures|last=Mould|first=Philip|date=1997-03-13|publisher=Fourth Estate|isbn=9781857025231|location=London|language=English}}</ref> and a number of lost works by [[Anthony van Dyck|Sir Anthony Van Dyck]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/jun/11/saleroom-sleuth-unearthed-van-dycks|title=Van Dyck paintings unearthed by saleroom sleuth|last=Alberge|first=Dalya|date=2011-06-11|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
Mould is the author of two books on art discovery and is widely consulted by the media on the subject. He is well known for his role co-presenting the BBC television programme ''[[Fake or Fortune?]]'', the most watched arts programme on television.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/its-a-copy-fake-or-fortune-stars-try-to-halt-rival-show-6gstpwtrz|title=It’s a copy: Fake or Fortune? stars try to halt rival show|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
==Biography==
[[File:Anglo-Flemish School, Arthur, Prince of Wales (Granard portrait) -003.png|thumb|right|upright|Portrait of [[Arthur, Prince of Wales]] (1486–1502) reidentified by Mould]]
Mould was educated at [[Kingsmead School, Hoylake]], [[Worth School]] and the [[University of East Anglia]] from where he graduated with a BA in History of Art in 1981.<ref>'MOULD, Philip Jonathan Clifford', Who's Who 2014, A & C Black, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 2014; online edn, Oxford University Press, Dec 2013</ref>
Mould's father owned a factory in Liverpool and his family was based in the Wirral.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/10560561/My-perfect-weekend-Philip-Mould-art-sleuth.html|title=My perfect weekend: Philip Mould, art sleuth|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> He developed an interest in antiques at an early age, thanks to his mother. She contracted polio as a child, and was in a wheelchair so would send Philip, aged six, into antiques shops to bring things out to her for inspection.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3827475/I-sold-signed-copy-John-Lennon-s-Mind-Games-50p-Philip-Mould-gives-definitive-answers-probing-questions.html|title=The definite article: This week it’s host Philip Mould|newspaper=Mail Online|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> Mould made friends with the owner of a local antiques shop, who taught him to read hallmarks on silver when he was just 11 or 12 years old, and by the age of 14 he was dealing in antique silver.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/10560561/My-perfect-weekend-Philip-Mould-art-sleuth.html|title=My perfect weekend: Philip Mould, art sleuth|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
Mould began art dealing in his early teens and has since established a leading art dealership specialising in British art, a subject on which he is internationally consulted.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bennett |first=Will |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1521012/Lost-portrait-reveals-the-soft-side-of-Elizabeth-I.html |title=Telegraph 12 June 2006 |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=12 June 2006 |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> He has sold works to public institutions such as [[Metropolitan Museum of Art|The Metropolitan Museum of Art]] (New York),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/426019|title=John Vanderbank, the younger {{!}} Self-Portrait {{!}} The Met|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art, i.e. The Met Museum|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> [[National Portrait Gallery (London)]], [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts Boston]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/portrait-of-a-lady-as-a-shepherdess-563890|title=Portrait of a Lady as a Shepherdess|date=2017-02-05|newspaper=Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref> [[Tate]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/richardson-portrait-of-the-artists-son-jonathan-richardson-the-younger-in-his-study-t13207|title="Portrait of the Artist’s Son, Jonathan Richardson the Younger, in his Study", Jonathan Richardson c.1734 {{!}} Tate|last=Tate|website=Tate|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> [[Huntington Library|The Huntington]] (California),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://emuseum.huntington.org/objects/12419/portrait-of-a-young-child?ctx=1dcfd205-5a0e-4d8f-8a1d-87aac4595541&idx=0|title=Portrait of a Young Child – Works – The Huntington Art Collections Online Catalog|website=emuseum.huntington.org|access-date=2017-02-14}}</ref> and the [[Royal Albert Memorial Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artfund.org/artsaved/search/philip+mould |title=The Art Fund, 'Art Saved' |publisher=Artfund.org |date= |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref>
Mould has worked as a valuer for the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] and the Government's [[Acceptance in Lieu]] scheme. Between 1988–2010 he acted as honorary art adviser to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] and the [[House of Lords]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Bennett |first=Will |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4722257/Bringing-art-into-politics.html |title=Telegraph 19 March 2001 |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=19 March 2001 |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> He is president of the charity Kids in Museums,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kidsinmuseums.org.uk/about/trustees/ |title=Kids in Museums website |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref> president and ex-chairman of [[Plantlife International]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.plantlife.org.uk/about_us/our_team/our_trustees/ |title=Plantlife International website |publisher=Plantlife.org.uk |date= |accessdate=22 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504094135/http://www.plantlife.org.uk/about_us/our_team/our_trustees/ |archivedate=4 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> a patron of [[Fight for Sight (UK)|Fight for Sight]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fightforsight.org.uk/press-release/items/philip-mould-obe-joins-fight-for-sight-as-patron-327|title=Philip Mould OBE joins Fight for Sight as patron – Fight for Sight|last=|first=|year=2013|work=fightforsight.org.uk|accessdate=19 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325113323/http://fightforsight.org.uk/press-release/items/philip-mould-obe-joins-fight-for-sight-as-patron-327|archivedate=25 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and a trustee and director of the [[Tony Banks, Baron Stratford|Tony Banks]] Memorial Trust for the acquisition of historical works for museums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tonybanks.org/ |title=Tony Banks Memorial Trust|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926094647/http://www.tonybanks.org/|archivedate=26 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.endole.co.uk/company/06208857/the-tony-banks-memorial-trust-limited |title=The Tony Banks Memorial Trust Limited - Company Information - Endole |first= |last= |work=endole.co.uk |year=2015 |accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> Mould is also a supporter of CleanupUK, and Pond Conservation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pondconservation.org.uk/about/News/pressreleases/millionpondsprojectlaunch/|title=Pond Conservation website|publisher=pondconservation.org.uk|date=|accessdate=22 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203082735/http://www.pondconservation.org.uk/about/News/pressreleases/millionpondsprojectlaunch/|archivedate=3 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was elected as a fellow of the [[Linnean Society]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://linnean.org/|title=The Linnean Society website|publisher=linnean.org |date= |accessdate=31 May 2012}}</ref>
Mould is a regular broadcaster, reviewer and writer for the national press. His television work includes writing and presenting the [[Channel 4]] series ''Changing Faces,'' and featuring as an expert on the ''[[Antiques Roadshow]].'' In 2011, he began co-hosting the television programme ''[[Fake or Fortune?]]'' with [[Fiona Bruce]].<ref name="FoF">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01mxxz6|title=Fake or Fortune?|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref> ''Fake or Fortune?'' now ranks as television's most popular arts show - regularly drawing an audience of 5 million - and has an international following.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/its-a-copy-fake-or-fortune-stars-try-to-halt-rival-show-6gstpwtrz|title=It’s a copy: Fake or Fortune? stars try to halt rival show|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
In January 2014, Mould warned of the increasing prevalence of what he termed "trapping" in which crooked sellers misleadingly hint that fake artworks have genuine provenance, without actually making false descriptions or asserting attributions.<ref name="Copping">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/10566055/Art-experts-warn-of-the-rise-of-the-trappers.html|title=Art experts warn of the rise of the 'trappers'|last=Copping|first=Jasper|date=12 January 2014|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref>
Mould is the author of two critically acclaimed books on art discovery, which are frequently cited as illuminating and well told insights into the workings of the old master trade, and have been published in America, Japan and China.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/5567418/Sleuth-The-Amazing-Quest-for-Lost-Art-Treasures-by-Philip-Mould-review.html|title=Sleuth: The Amazing Quest for Lost Art Treasures by Philip Mould: review|last=Reid|first=By Aileen|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
In recognition of his art world expertise and contribution to portrait heritage he was created [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in the [[2005 New Year Honours]] list.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/news/nyhons05.htm |title=The British Theatre Guide: New Year Honours List 2005 |publisher=Britishtheatreguide.info |date=4 January 2005 |accessdate=6 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050122024515/http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/news/nyhons05.htm |archivedate=22 January 2005 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> For his achievements in his field, as well as his involvement with numerous charities and broadcasting, Mould received an [[honorary doctorate]] in July 2013 at his [[Alma mater|former university]], the [[University of East Anglia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uea.ac.uk/mac/comm/media/press/2013/May/hon-grads|title=UEA to honour notable alumni at its 50th anniversary graduation|date=21 May 2013|publisher=University of East Anglia|accessdate=13 January 2014}}</ref>
In August 2014, Mould was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' opposing [[Scottish independence]] in the run-up to September's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|referendum on that issue]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/07/celebrities-open-letter-scotland-independence-full-text |title=Celebrities' open letter to Scotland – full text and list of signatories | Politics |publisher=theguardian.com |date=2014-08-07 |accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
In October 2015 Mould appeared on BBC's ''[[Gardeners' World]]'', in the garden of his home, discussing his passion for nature and talked of his interest in varieties of rose which would have been grown in the time of [[Anthony van Dyck|Sir Anthony van Dyck]]. He also discussed the work of one of his favourite artists, [[Cedric Morris]], who was also a great [[plantsman]].<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06h3zs2 |title=BBC Two - Gardeners' World, 2015, Episode 29 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=9 October 2015 |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> Mould is a keen collector of Morris's work (for his private collection), and champions modern British artists in general; he cites the [[Bloomsbury Group]] amongst his favourites.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/10560561/My-perfect-weekend-Philip-Mould-art-sleuth.html|title=My perfect weekend: Philip Mould, art sleuth|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-02-14|language=en}}</ref>
== Bibliography == * {{cite book |date=1995 |title=Sleepers: In Search of Lost Old Masters |location=London |publisher=Fourth Estate |isbn=978-1857022186 }}, retitled in paperback as... * {{cite book |date=1997 |title=The Trail of Lot 163: In Search of Lost Art Treasures |location=London |publisher=Fourth Estate |isbn=978-1857025231 }} * {{cite book |date=2009 |title=Sleuth: The Amazing Quest for Lost Art Treasures |location=London |publisher=HarperCollins |isbn=978-0007281367 }}, retitled for US edition as... ** {{cite book |date=2010 |title=The Art Detective: Fakes, Frauds and Finds and the Search for Lost Treasures |location=New York |publisher=Viking |isbn=978-0670021857 }}
== Personal life == Philip Mould lives with his wife Catherine and son Oliver at their house in [[Kensington]], London and a seventeenth-century manor house in Oxfordshire close to [[Chipping Norton]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Period Property |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/periodproperty/8731501/BBC-presenter-Philip-Moulds-Duck-End-house-Oxfordshire.html |title=BBC presenter Philip Mould's Duck End house, Oxfordshire |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |date= |accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref>

[[File:Arsenale (Venice) - First Ancient Greek lion.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Ancient Greek lion statue at the Arsenal, Venice.]] The '''Piraeus Lion''' ({{lang-it|Leone del Pireo}}; {{lang-sv|Pireuslejonet}}); is one of four [[lion]] statues on display at the [[Venetian Arsenal]], where it was displayed as a symbol of Venice's patron saint, [[Saint Mark]].
== History == It was originally located in [[Piraeus]], the harbour of [[Athens]]. It was looted by Venetian naval commander [[Francesco Morosini]] in 1687 as [[plunder]] taken in the [[Great Turkish War]] against the [[Ottoman Empire]], during which the Venetians [[Siege of the Acropolis (1687)|captured Athens]] and Morosini's cannons caused damage to the [[Parthenon]] only matched by his subsequent looting.<ref>Encyclopædia Britannica, Athens, The Acropolis, p.6/20, 2008, O.Ed.</ref> Copies of the statue can also be seen at the [[Piraeus Archaeological Museum]] and the [[Swedish Museum of National Antiquities]] in [[Stockholm]].
The lion was originally sculpted in about 360 BC,<ref>Cornelius Vermeule, "Greek Funerary Animals, 450-300 B. C.", ''American Journal of Archaeology'' '''76''':1:49-59 (January 1972), {{jstor|503610}}, p. 53</ref> and became a famous landmark in Piraeus, having stood there since the 1st or 2nd century AD. Its prominence was such that the port eventually became referred to in Italian as Porto Leone ("Lion Port") as the port's original name ceased to be used.<ref>Goette, Hans Rupprecht (2001), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=FRHY3zWyrcEC Athens, Attica and the Megarid: An Archaeological Guide]''. [[Routledge]]. p. 141. {{ISBN|0-415-24370-X}}</ref> It is depicted in a sitting pose, with a hollow throat and the mark of a pipe (now lost) running down its back; this suggests that it was originally used as a fountain.<ref>Ellis, Henry (1833). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=1K_TIaJxo8EC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false The British Museum. Elgin and Phigaleian Marbles]''. [[British Museum]]. p. 36.</ref> This is consistent with the description of the statue from the 1670s, which said that water flowed from the lion's mouth into a cistern at its feet.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Jarring |first=Gunnar |authorlink= |title=Evliya Celebi och Marmorlejonet från Pireus |journal=[[Fornvännen]] |volume=85 |pages=1–4 |publisher=[[Swedish National Heritage Board]] |year=1978 |url=http://fornvannen.se/pdf/1970talet/1978_001.pdf |issn=1404-9430 |accessdate=5 September 2010}}.</ref>
The statue, which is made of white [[marble]] and stands some 3 m (9 ft.) high, is particularly noteworthy for having been defaced some time in the second half of the 11th century by Scandinavians who carved two lengthy [[Runic alphabet|runic]] inscriptions into the shoulders and flanks of the lion.<ref>[[T. D. Kendrick|Kendrick, Thomas D.]] (2004). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=3Z8NgXgRytUC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false A History of the Vikings]''. Courier Dover Publications. p. 176. {{ISBN|0-486-43396-X}}</ref> The runes are carved in the shape of an elaborate [[lindworm]] dragon-headed [[scroll]], in much the same style as on [[runestone]]s in [[Scandinavia]].<ref name=BussLion>"The Book of THoTH (Leaves of Wisdom) — Dragon" (notes), URL: [http://www.book-of-thoth.com/thebook/index.php/Dragon BT-Dragon] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325220622/http://www.book-of-thoth.com/thebook/index.php/Dragon |date=25 March 2008 }}.</ref> The carvers of the runes were almost certainly [[Varangians]], Scandinavian mercenaries in the service of the [[Byzantine Emperor | Byzantine (Eastern Roman) Emperor]].
== Inscriptions and translations == [[File:Pireuslejonet.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Piraeus Lion drawing of curved [[lindworm]] inscription (shoulder/flank).]] [[File:6003 - Venezia - Arsenale - Scritta runica su leone greco (1040) - Foto Giovanni Dall'Orto, 3-Aug-2007.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Photo of inscription on right flank of lion (with contrast exaggerated to make inscription more visible).]] [[File:Lion runes drawing.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Drawing of the same inscription.]] The inscriptions were not recognised as runes until the Swedish diplomat [[Johan David Åkerblad]] identified them at the end of the 18th century. They are in the shape of a [[lindworm]] (a flightless dragon with serpentine body and two or no legs) and were first translated in the mid-19th century by [[Carl Christian Rafn]], the Secretary of the Kongelige Nordiske Oldskrift-Selskab (Royal Society of Nordic Antiquaries).<ref name="Rafn">{{Cite book |last=Rafn |first=Carl Christian |authorlink=Carl Christian Rafn |contribution=En Nordisk Runeindskrift i Piræus, med Forklaring af C. C. Rafn |title=Antiquarisk Tidsskrift: Udgivet af det Kongelige Nordiske Oldskrift-Selskab 1855-57 |publisher= |year=1857 |location= |pages=3–69 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7khBAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=f}}</ref> The inscriptions are heavily eroded due to weathering and air pollution in [[Venice]], making many of the individual runes barely legible. This has required translators to reconstruct some of the runes, filling in the blanks to determine what words they represented.
There have been several attempts to decipher and translate the text. Below follow Rafn's early attempt (1854) and Eric Brate's attempt (1914), which is considered to be the most successful one.<ref name="Pritsak348">[[Omeljan Pritsak|Pritsak, Omeljan]]. (1981). ''The Origin of Rus'.'' Cambridge, Mass.: Distributed by Harvard University Press for the Harvard Ukrainian Research Institute. p. 348. {{ISBN|0-674-64465-4}}</ref>
== Rafn's translation == Rafn's attempt is as follows, with the legible letters shown in bold and the reconstructed ones unbolded:<ref>A. Craig Gibson, "Runic Inscriptions: Anglo-Saxon and Scandinavian", in ''Transactions of the Historic Society of Lancashire and Cheshire'', p. 130. Historic Society of Lancashire and Cheshire, 1902</ref><ref>Rafn, Carl Christian (1856). "Inscription runique du Pirée - Runeindskrift i Piraeeus", Impr. de Thiele</ref>
Right side of the lion:
* '''ASMUDR : HJU : '''RU'''NAR : ÞISAR : ÞAIR : ISK'''IR : AUK: ÞU'''RLIFR : ÞURÞR : AUK : IVA'''R : AT : '''BON : H'''A'''RADS : '''H'''AF'''A : '''ÞUAT : GRIK'''I'''AR : '''UF : H'''UGSA'''ÞU : AUK : B'''A'''NAÞU :''' ** ''Asmund cut these runes with Asgeir and Thorleif, Thord and Ivar, at the request of Harold the Tall, though the Greeks considered about and forbade it.''
Left side of the lion:
* '''HAKUN : VAN: ÞI'''R''' : ULFR : '''A'''UK : ASM'''U'''D'''R : A'''UK : A'''U'''RN : HAFN : ÞESA : ÞIR : M'''E'''N : L'''AG'''ÞU : A : U'''K''' : HARAD'''R''' : HA'''F'''I : UF IABUTA : UPRA'''R'''S'''TAR : '''V'''EGNA : '''GRI'''K'''IAÞIÞS : VARÞ : DALK'''R''' : N'''A'''U'''ÞUGR : I : F'''IAR'''I : LAÞUM : EGIL : VAR : '''I''' : FARU : '''MIÞ : '''RAGNAR'''R : TIL : '''RU'''MAN'''IU''' . . . . AUK : A'''RMENIU :''' ** ''Hakon with Ulf and Asmund and Örn conquered this port. These men and Harold Hafi imposed a heavy fine on account of the revolt of the Greek people. Dalk is detained captive in far lands. Egil is gone on an expedition with Ragnar into [[Byzantine Empire|Romania]] and [[Armenia]].''
Some have tried to trace [[Harald Hardrade]]'s name on the inscription, but the time it was carved does not coincide with his time in the service of the emperor.<ref>Heath, Ian (1985). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=aEyQe18JWvUC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false The Vikings]'' Osprey Publishing. {{ISBN|0-85045-565-0}}</ref>
== Erik Brate's translation == [[Erik Brate]]'s interpretation from 1914 is considered to be the most successful one.<ref name="Pritsak348"/> {| | :'''hiuku þir hilfninks milum''' :'''hna en i hafn þesi þir min''' :'''eoku runar at haursa bunta''' :'''kuþan a uah''' :'''riþu suiar þita linu''' :'''fur raþum kul uan farin''' :- :'''tri(n)kiar ristu runar''' :'''[a rikan strin]k hiuku''' :'''þair isk[il-] [þu]rlifr''' :- :'''litu auka ui[i þir a]''' :'''roþrslanti b[yku] -''' :'''a sun iuk runar þisar.''' :'''ufr uk - li st[intu]''' :'''a[t haursa]''' :'''kul] uan farn'''<ref name="Pritsak348"/> | :They cut him down in the midst of his :forces. But in the harbor the men cut :runes by the sea in memory of Horsi, a :good warrior. :The Swedes set this on the lion. :He went his way with good counsel, ::gold he won in his travels. :The warriors cut runes, :hewed them in an ornamental scroll. :Æskell (Áskell) [and others] and ::Þorlæifʀ (Þorleifr) :had them well cut, they who lived :in [[Roslagen]]. [N. N.] son of [N. N.] :cut these runes. :Ulfʀ (Úlfr) and [N. N.] colored them :in memory of Horsi. :He won gold in his travels.<ref name="Pritsak348"/> | |}

'''School of Paris''' refers to the many [[Manuscript illumination|manuscript illuminators]], whose identities are mostly unknown, who made Paris an internationally important centre of illumination throughout the [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] and [[Gothic art|Gothic]] periods of the [[Middle Ages]], and for some time into the [[Renaissance]].<ref>[http://metmuseum.org/toah/ht/08/euwf.html France 1400-1600, Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History]</ref> The most famous of these artists were [[Master Honoré]],<ref>Branner, Robert (1977) ''Manuscript Painting in Paris During the Reign of Saint Louis: A Study of Styles''. Berkeley: University of California Press]</ref> [[Jean Pucelle]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gould|first1=Karen|title=Jean Pucelle and Northern Gothic Art: New Evidence from Strasbourg Cathedral |journal=The Art Bulletin |date=March 1992 |volume=74|issue=1|page=51 |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/3045850?sid=21106100409263&uid=3739808&uid=4&uid=3739256&uid=2#page_scan_tab_contents|accessdate=12 March 2015|doi=10.2307/3045850}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Randall|first1=Lilian|title=Reviewed Work: Jean Pucelle by Kathleen Morand|journal=Speculum|date=April 1964|volume=39|issue=2|page=331|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/2852746?sid=21106100403773&uid=2&uid=3739256&uid=4&uid=3739808#page_scan_tab_contents|accessdate=12 March 2015|doi=10.2307/2852746}}</ref> and [[Jean Fouquet]].<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/214842/Jean-Fouquet Encyclopaedia Britannica]</ref>
The [[Limbourg brothers]],<ref>[http://artpaintingartist.org/limbourg-brothers-1385-1416-among-the-last-illuminators-of-the-medieval-art/ Limbourg brothers (1385-1416) – Among the last Illuminators of the Medieval Art]</ref> originally from the Netherlands, also spent time in Paris, as well as [[Burgundy (region)|Burgundy]] and [[Bourges]], but their style is not typical of the School of Paris of the day.
Many of the painters in Parisian workshops were women.

'''Scopophilia''' or '''scoptophilia''' (from {{lang-grc|σκοπέω}} {{lang|grc-Latn|skopeō}}, "look to, examine" and {{lang|grc|φῐλῐ́ᾱ}} {{lang|grc-Latn|philíā}}, "tendency toward"), is deriving pleasure from looking. As an expression of [[Human sexuality|sexuality]], it refers to [[sexual pleasure]] derived from looking at erotic objects: erotic photographs, [[pornography]], [[nudity|naked bodies]], etc.
==Psychoanalysis==
The term was introduced to translate [[Freud]]'s {{lang|de|Schaulust}}, or pleasure in looking.<ref>[[Jacques Lacan]], ''The Four Fundamental Concepts of Psycho-Analysis'' (1994) p. 194</ref> Freud considered pleasure in looking to be a regular partial instinct in childhood,<ref>Sigmund Freud, ''On Sexuality'' (PFL 7) pp. 109–10</ref> which might be sublimated into interest in art, or alternatively become fixated into what the [[Rat Man]] called "a burning and tormenting curiosity to see the female body".<ref>Quoted in Sigmund Freud, ''Case Histories II'' (PFL 9) pp. 41–2</ref>
Freud thought that inhibition of scopophilia might lead to actual disturbances of vision;<ref>Sigmund Freud, ''On Psychopathology'' (PFL 10) pp. 112–3</ref> other analysts have suggested that it might lead to a retreat from concrete objects into a world of abstractions.<ref>Otto Fenichel, ''The Psychoanalytic Theory of Neurosis'' (1946) p. 177</ref>
Scopophilia was developed in the psychoanalytic theorizing of [[Otto Fenichel]], with special reference to [[Identification (psychology)|identification]].<ref>Otto Fenichel, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zk5gPgAACAAJ&dq=the+collected+papers+of+otto+fenichel&hl=en&ei=ZhhhTbTNGc3Oswa3uLW1CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ ''The Scoptophilic Instinct and Identification''] (1953) {{ISBN|0-393-33741-3}}</ref> Fenichel maintained that "a child who is looking for libidinous purposes...wants to look at an object in order to 'feel along with him'".<ref>Fenichel, ''Theory'', p. 71</ref> He also explored how looking could substitute for acting in those anxious to avoid guilt.<ref>Fenichel, ''Theory'', p. 348</ref>
[[Jacques Lacan]] subsequently drew on [[Sartre]]'s theory of the gaze to link scopophilia with the apprehension of the other: "the gaze is this object lost and suddenly refound in the conflagration of shame, by the introduction of the other".<ref>Lacan, p. 183</ref> Lacan privileged scopophilia in his theory of how desire is captured by the [[The Imaginary (psychoanalysis)|imaginary]] image of the other;<ref>Jacques Lacan, ''Television'' (1990) p. 86</ref> other French analysts have emphasised how the discovery of sexual difference in childhood, and the accompanying sense of not knowing subsequently fuels the scopophilic drive.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schneiderman|first1=Stuart|title=Returning to Freud: Clinical Psychoanalysis in the School of Lacan|date=1980|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=9780300039320|page=224}}</ref>
==Cinema==
[[Voyeurism]] plays a role in the films of [[Alfred Hitchcock]], most notably in the 1960 film, ''[[Psycho (1960 film)|Psycho]]''. In the film, [[Norman Bates]] is revealed to have a peephole to one of the hotel rooms. He uses this to spy on [[Marion Crane]], while she is in a state of undress.
Scopophilia is mentioned by name in director Michael Powell's ''Peeping Tom'' (1960). The entire film is an exercise in voyeurism. Powell, and his screenwriter, Leo Marks, created to prove to what extent how one is capable of watching things one shouldn't watch. At the same time, Powell created a psychological essay about what makes Mark Lewis, the central character of the film, act the way he acted. Mark has been scarred for life thanks to what his own father did to him during a period of his growing years that formed his character into the reclusive man who feels at home doing the despicable crimes he commits. (I.M.D.B.)
Building on Lacan's work,<ref>Jane Mills,[https://books.google.com/books?id=65HbQfMKmAIC&pg=PA223&dq=scopophobia&lr= "The Money Shot"] (2001) {{ISBN|1-86403-142-5}}, p. 223</ref> scopophilia was used by [[Film|cinema]] [[psychoanalysis|psychoanalyst]]s of the 1970s to describe pleasures (often considered pathological) and other unconscious processes occurring in spectators when they watch films.<ref>John Thornton Caldwell, [https://books.google.com/books?id=59S8pfkFb-IC&pg=PA342&dq=scopophobia#PPA343,M1 ''Televisuality: Style, Crisis, and Authority in American Television''] (1995) {{ISBN|0-8135-2164-5}}, p. 343</ref> [[Voyeurism]] and the [[male gaze]] have been seen as central elements in such mainstream cinematic viewing,<ref>J. Childers/G. Hentzi, ''The Columbia Dictionary of Modern Literary and Cultural Criticism'' (1995) pp. 316–17</ref> and are most famously discussed in [[Laura Mulvey]]'s influential 1975 essay "Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema".<ref>{{cite book|last=Mulvey|first=Laura|title=Visual and Other Pleasures|year=2009|publisher=Palgrave MacMillan|location=England|isbn=978-1-4039-9246-8|pages=14–27}}</ref>
Others, however, have objected to the element of [[scapegoating]] in such an analysis of the variegated pleasures of movie-viewing.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Miklitsch|first1=Robert|title=Roll over Adorno: Critical Theory, Popular Culture, Audiovisual Media|date=2006|publisher=[[State University of New York Press]]|isbn=978-0791467336|pages=93–94|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Roll_Over_Adorno.html?id=oCprHBiGYoMC}}</ref>
==Race==
[[Critical race theory|Critical race theorists]], such as [[bell hooks]],<ref>bell hooks, [https://books.google.com/books?id=8bCqfK3m3GsC&q "Eating the Other"], 2006 {{ISBN|1-4288-1629-1}}</ref> David Marriott,<ref>David Marriott, "Bordering On: The Black Penis", (1996), ''[[Textual Practice]]'' 10(1), pp. 9–28.</ref> and Shannon Winnubst,<ref>Shannon Winnubst, [https://books.google.com/books?id=v8HwslvL598C&pg=PA17&dq=queer+freedom&hl=en&ei=HRxhTZv9M4jNswbY9IC2CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=is%20the%20mirror%20racist&f=false "Is the Mirror Racist?: Interrogating the Space of Whiteness"], (2006) {{ISBN|0-253-21830-6}}</ref> have also taken up scopophilia and the scopic drive as a mechanism to describe racial "other-ing" (c.f. [[scopophobia]]).
In their theories scopophilia is a question of fixing the appearance and identity of the other through the gaze. So cultural scopophilia restricts the visible representations of racial identity that it allows.<ref>Todd W. Reeser, ''Masculinities in Theory'' (2011) pp. 164–5</ref>
==Literary examples== * The ''[[Satyricon]]'' of [[Gaius Petronius Arbiter]] is pervaded with scopophilia, as when a priestess of [[Priapus]] was "the first to put an inquisitive eye to a crack she had naughtily opened, and spy on their play with prurient eagerness".<ref>Petronius, ''[[The Satyricon]]'' (Penguin 1986) p. 50 and p. 188</ref> * In ''Secret Sexualities'', Ian McCormick notes the inter-relationship of public and private, and of the open and the secret, as features that constitute transgressive or forbidden sexualities. In this respect, there is an example from Fanny's observation of two sodomites in ''Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure'' (1749): 'at length I observed a paper patch of the same colour as the wainscot, which I took to conceal some flaw; but then it was so high, that I was obliged to stand upon a chair to reach it, which I did as soft as possible, and, with a point of a bodkin, soon pierced it, and opened myself espial room sufficient. And now, applying my eye close, I commanded the room perfectly, and could see my two young sparks romping and pulling one another about, entirely, to my imagination, in frolic and innocent play.' <ref>McCormick, Ian. ''Secret Sexualities: A Sourcebook of 17th and 18th Century Writing''. Routledge, 1997. pp. 1-11; p. 158. See also George E. Haggerty. "Keyhole testimony: witnessing sodomy in the eighteenth century." ''The Eighteenth Century'' 44, no. 2/3 (2003): 167-182.</ref>

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Social gravity''' was an application of [[Newtonian gravity]] to the system of commerce influence.
For instance, in ''The Administration of the Colonies'' (1764), [[Thomas Pownall]] (1722–1805) used the Newtonian concept of "attraction" to form the basis of his political and commercial theory of empire. Pownall's vision provided an important explanation of the mechanism by which colonial theorists understood the possibility of empire being "transferred" from one state to another. Pownall applied the Newtonian concept of gravity to his theory of empire, as evident in his suggestion that the "laws of nature" held the colonies to [[Great Britain]] in a manner "analogous in all cases, by which the center of gravity in the solar system" held the planets in their orbits. In making this analogy, Pownall's notion of 'social gravity' drew upon earlier visions of social cohesion, particularly ideas of sociability in eighteenth-century Britain. These ideas, in turn, were often predicated upon Stoic notions of [[cosmopolitanism]], expressed by the key term [[oikeiôsis]], in order to stress the "moral" imperative for like-minded humans to forge bonds dedicated to the common good.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Breuninger |first=Scott |date=Summer 2006 |title='Social Gravity' and the Translatio Tradition in Early American Theories of Empire |journal=Southern Quarterly |volume=43 |issue=4 |pages=70–108}}</ref>

} </score>|width=120|caption=Three notes with staccato dots}}'''Staccato''' ({{IPA-it|stakˈkaːto|}}; Italian for "detached") is a form of [[Articulation (music)|musical articulation]]. In modern notation, it signifies a note of shortened duration,<ref>Willi Apel, ''Harvard Dictionary of Music'' (Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press, 1960), p. 708.</ref><ref>Michael Kennedy, ed., {{Full|date=June 2015}}<!--The page citation is nice, but it is customary to cite dictionary entries by title.-->''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Music'', third edition (Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 1980), p. 617.</ref> separated from the note that may follow by silence.<ref>Geoffrey Chew, "Staccato", ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', second edition, edited by [[Stanley Sadie]] and [[John Tyrrell (professor of music)|John Tyrrell]] (London: Macmillan Publishers, 2001).</ref> It has been described by theorists and has appeared in music since at least 1676.<ref>Werner Bachmann, Robert E. Seletsky, [[David D. Boyden]], Jaak Liivoja-Lorius, Peter Walls, and Peter Cooke, "Bow", ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', second edition, edited by [[Stanley Sadie]] and [[John Tyrrell (musicologist)|John Tyrrell]] (London: Macmillan Publishers, 2001).</ref>
== Notation == {{listen | filename = Without staccato.ogg | title = Music played without staccato | description = | format = [[Ogg]] | filename2 = With staccato.ogg | title2 = The same music played with staccato | description2 = | format2 = [[Ogg]] bbad | title3 = Bassoon articulations | description3 = A [[bassoon]] played '''staccato''', [[legato]], [[legato]] + [[vibrato]], and [[slur (music)|slurred]]. | format3 = [[Ogg]] }} In 20th-century music, a dot placed above or below a note indicates that it should be played staccato, and a wedge is used for the more emphatic [[staccatissimo]]. However, before 1850, dots, dashes, and wedges were all likely to have the same meaning, even though some theorists from as early as the 1750s distinguished different degrees of staccato through the use of dots and dashes, with the dash indicating a shorter, sharper note, and the dot a longer, lighter one.
A number of signs came to be used in the late 19th and early 20th centuries to discriminate more subtle nuances of staccato. These signs involve various combinations of dots, vertical and horizontal dashes, vertical and horizontal wedges, and the like, but attempts to standardize these signs have not generally been successful.<ref>Geoffrey Chew, "Staccato", ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', second edition, edited by [[Stanley Sadie]] and [[John Tyrrell (professor of music)|John Tyrrell]] (London: Macmillan Publishers, 2001).</ref>
The example below illustrates the scope of the staccato dot:
:<score> { \override Score.TimeSignature #'stencil = ##f << \clef treble \relative c' { \stemNeutral <e c'>-. <g d'>-. <g e'>-. <c, c'>-. \stemUp a'-. c-. c-. d-. } \\ { s1 f'4 f' g' g' } >>
} </score>
In the first measure, the pairs of notes are in the same musical [[Part (music)|part]] (or voice) since they are on a common stem. The staccato applies to both notes of the pairs. In the second measure, the pairs of notes are stemmed separately indicating two different parts, so the staccato applies only to the upper note.
The opposite musical articulation of staccato is [[legato]], signifying long and continuous notes.<ref>Michael Kennedy and Joyce Bourne, "Staccato", ''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Music''{{Full|date=June 2015}}<!--Third edition 1980 cited elsewhere in this article; is this the fourth, fifth, or some other edition?--> (Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 1996).</ref> There is an intermediate articulation called either [[mezzo staccato]] or [[non legato]].
By default, in the music notation program [[Sibelius (software)|Sibelius]], "staccatos shorten a note by 50%."<ref>Daniel Spreadbury, Michael Eastwood, Ben Finn, and Jonathan Finn, "Sibelius 5 Reference", edition 5.2 (March 2008), p. 284.</ref>
== Staccatissimo == In [[musical notation]], '''staccatissimo''' (plural: ''staccatissimi'' or the [[Anglicisation|anglicised]] form ''staccatissimos'') indicates that the notes are to be played extremely separated and distinct, a superlative staccato. This can be notated with little pikes over or under the notes, depending on [[Stem (music)|stem]] direction, as in this example from [[Anton Bruckner|Bruckner]]'s [[Symphony No. 0 (Bruckner)|Symphony No. 0 in D minor]]:
: <score> \new Score { \new Staff { \relative c' { \time 3/4 \key d \minor \clef treble d8->(\ff cis d2~ d4) a'-! d-! es-! e-! f-! fis-! g-! gis-! a8(-> gis a4) } } } </score>
Alternatively, it can be notated by writing the word "staccatissimo" or the abbreviation "staccatiss." over the staff. A few composers, such as Mozart, have used staccato dots accompanied by a written instruction ''staccatissimo'' when they mean the passage to be played ''staccatissimo''.<ref>Philip Farkas, ''The Art of French Horn Playing'' (Evanston: Summy-Birchard Company, 1956): p. 51. {{ISBN|978-0-87487-021-3}}.</ref>

'''Synantherology''' is the study of the plant family [[Asteraceae]] (also called [[Compositae]]). The name of the field refers to the fused [[anther]]s possessed by members of the family, and recalls an old French name, ''synantherées'', for the family.
Although many of the plants of the Asteraceae were described for the European community at least as long ago as [[Theophrastus]],<ref>{{ cite journal | title = The Compositae Revisited | author = Arthur Cronquist | journal = Brittonia | volume = 29 | issue = 2 | date = Apr–Jun 1977 | pages = 137–153 | doi = 10.2307/2805847 | jstor = 2805847 }}</ref> an organization of the family into [[tribe (biology)|tribe]]s, which remained largely stable throughout the 20th century, was published in 1873 by [[George Bentham]].<ref>{{cite journal |last = Panero |first = JL |author2=VA Funk |title = Toward a phylogenetic subfamilial classification for the Compositae (Asteraceae) |journal = Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington |volume = 115 |issue = 4 |pages = 909–922 |publisher = Biological Society of Washington |date = 2002-12-30 |url = http://www.mnh.si.edu/biodiversity/bdg/Panero&Funk2002.pdf |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060914213409/http://www.mnh.si.edu/biodiversity/bdg/Panero%26Funk2002.pdf |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2006-09-14 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 |format = – <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3A+intitle%3AToward+a+phylogenetic+subfamilial+classification+for+the+Compositae+%28Asteraceae%29&as_publication=Proceedings+of+the+Biological+Society+of+Washington&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup>}} </ref>
In a 1970 article titled "The New Synantherology", [[Harold E. Robinson]] advocated greater attention to microstructures (studied with the [[compound light microscope]]). He was not the first, as [[Alexandre de Cassini]] and others of the 19th century split species based on fine distinctions of microstructure, a tendency which Bentham found excessive.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Microcharacters as Generic Markers in the Eupatorieae | author = Randall W. Scott | journal = Taxon | volume = 34 | issue = 1 | date = Feb 1985 | pages =26–30 | doi = 10.2307/1221560 | jstor = 1221560 }}</ref>
Noted United States synantherologists include:
* T. M. Barkley * V. A. Funk * D. J. Keil * R. M. King * [[Harold E. Robinson]] * J. A. Soule * T. F. Steussy * [[Billie Lee Turner Sr.]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} There are four basic theatrical forms either defined, implied, or derived by or from Aristotle: Tragedy; Comedy; Melodrama; and Drama. Any number of styles can be used to convey these forms.
A good working definition of, "Style", is ''how'' something is done. Theatrical styles are influenced by their time and place, artistic and other social structures, as well as the individual style of the particular artist or artists. As theater is a mongrel art form, a production may or may not have stylistic integrity with regard to script, acting, direction, design, music, and venue.
==Styles==
There are a variety of '''theatrical styles''' used in theater/drama. These include
'''[[Naturalism (theater)|Naturalism]]''' Portraying life on stage with a close attention to detail, based on observation of real life. Cause and effect are central to the script's structure, with the subjects focused on conflicts of "nature vs. nurture", the natural order of things, survival, notions of evolution. The production style is one of everyday reality.
'''[[Theatrical realism|Realism]]''' Portraying characters on stage that are close to real life, with realistic settings and staging. Realism is an effort to satisfy all the theatrical conventions necessary to the production, but to do so in a way that seems to be "normal" life.
'''[[Expressionism]]''' Anti-realistic in seeing appearance as distorted and the truth lying within man. The outward appearance on stage can be distorted and unrealistic to portray an eternal truth or internal emotional conflict.
'''[[Theater of the Absurd|Absurdity]]''' Presents a perspective that all human attempts at significance are illogical. Ultimate truth is chaos with little certainty. There is no necessity that need drive us.
'''[[Epic Theatre]]''' As devised by Bertolt Brecht, epic theatre forces audience members to constantly return to rational observation, rather than emotional immersion. Sudden bursts of song, elements of absurdity and breaches of the fourth wall are all prime examples of how this rational observation is constantly revitalized; this idea is known as Verfremdungseffekt.
'''[[Melodrama]]''' As devised by early Greek dramatists, these styles rely on stock characters and stereotypes to portray stories in an exaggerated way, either tragic or comic. Links to '''commedia dell'arte'''.
'''[[Theatre of Cruelty]]''' As developed by Antonin Artaud, a style that encourages the shock and horror of the audience, through the excessive use of light and sound, instead of active entertainment or emotional relaxation.
'''[[Physical theatre]]''' A modernist approach to theatre which centralises a performer's movement as the key communicator of a play's storytelling.
'''[[Poor theatre]]''' Developed by Jerzy Growotski, this genre believes in the stripping back of set, props, costume, light and sound to allow focus to be placed solely upon the actors, their characterisation and the underlying human relationships.
'''[[Immersive theatre]]''' Developed by Augusto Boal, these styles all place focus on the audience member's individuality: their personal decisions, opinions and emotions, and how that impacts those of the characters onstage. The audience firmly exists within the 'world of the play'. Links to '''Promenade''' and '''Forum''' theatre.

'''Transnational history''' is a field of [[history]] that looks at how developments within the history of one [[country]] have been shaped by developments outside of this country, e.g. how [[History of the British Isles|British history]] has been shaped by developments coming from [[France]], [[Germany]] or [[the US]]. The idea of transnationalism can be traced back to 1991, when [[Ian Tyrrell]] pioneered this approach but it was in the field of [[American Studies]], in the late 1990s, that the concept really was developed. Since then the term has been adopted by the field of history.
As the concept is still relatively new with the field of history, a consensus has not emerged on how to define the term precisely. However, [[Denmark|Danish]] [[historian]] Nils Arne Sørensen emphasizes that an important feature of transnational history is to reject the [[nation state]] as the "natural" frame for historical analysis. This redirection of historical studies can be seen as countermove to the fact that the field of history was founded in the 19th century while the [[nationalism|nationalist]] movement was on the rise in Europe.<ref>Nils Arne Sørensen (2009) "[https://tidsskrift.dk/historisktidsskrift/article/view/56424/76630 Den transnationale vending?]"i ''[[Historisk Tidsskrift (Denmark)|Historisk Tidsskrift]]'' Volume 109, Issue 2: 459-472.</ref> Akira Iriye and Pierre-Yves Saunier define transnational history as having to do with the "connections and circulations" between societies in the [[modern age]].<ref>Akira Iriye and Pierre-Yves Saunier (2009) ''Palgrave Dictionary of Transnational History''. Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan.</ref> Ian Tyrrell argues that transnational history is related to the [[Annales school]].<ref>Ian Tyrrell (2008) [https://iantyrrell.wordpress.com/what-is-transnational-history/ "What is transnational history?"] ''Ian Tyrell'' (blog)</ref>
